channel.title: A Prairie Home Companion Archive
channel.description: Archive of A Prairie Home Companion episodes

item.title: February 7, 1998 rebroadcast with Jean Redpath and Studs Terkel
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: a gem from February 1998 at the Fitzgerald Theater in Saint Paul, Minnesota. Radio pioneer Studs Terkel joins us for a few stories and reads poems by Robert Frost and William Butler Yeats, and our friend and folksinger Jean Redpath performs "The Spinning Wheel" and "Women of Our Time." Plus: Guy Noir drowns his sorrows and chats with a former radio man at the Five Spot Bar, The Guy's All-Star Shoe Band plays "Fidgety Feet," and a message from Bertha's Kitty Boutique. In Lake Wobegon, the host recalls the Native Americans, government agents, Unitarian missionaries, and hippie farmers who've lived in Lake Wobegon over the years.

item.title: September 26, 2015 rebroadcast with Sierra Hull and Heather Masse
September 20, 2014 rebroadcast with Hot Rize, Sara Watkins, Howard Levy, and Lynn Peterson
September 1, 2017 broadcast with Jearlyn & Jevetta Steele, Aoife O'Donovan, Heather Masse, the State Fair All-Star Fiddle Formation, and the Anoka High School Marching Tornadoes
item.description: This week: Garrison returns to the Minnesota State Fair Grandstand in Falcon Heights, Minnesota with The Minnesota Show. We'll be joined by Jearlyn and Jevetta Steele, Aoife O'Donovan, Heather Masse, the State Fair All-Star Fiddle Formation -- 14 local fiddle players -- and the Anoka High School Marching Tornadoes. Plus: Richard Dworsky and the Dworsky Orchestra (Richard Kriehn on mandolin and fiddle, bassist Larry Kohut, Chris Siebold on guitar, and drummer Gerald Dowd); our Royal Academy of Radio Actors, Tim Russell, Sue Scott, and Fred Newman; and, of course, an update on all the latest News from Lake Wobegon.

item.title: June 5, 2010 rebroadcast with Elvin Bishop and Sara and Sean Watkins
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: a show originally from June 2010 at the Santa Barbara Bowl in Santa Barbara, California. Bluesman Elvin Bishop plays "Keep a Dollar in Your Pocket" and "Fishin'," and siblings Sara and Sean Watkins play "Polly Put the Kettle On" and John Prine's "The Late John Garfield Blues." Plus: Sara joins Garrison on "Gold Watch and Chain," Guy Noir gets involved in a dispute between two castle-dwelling neighbors, and The Guy's All-Star Shoe Band plays the "Thelonious Boogie." In Lake Wobegon, the Lutheran Church holds a graduation dinner.

item.title: April 9, 2005 rebroadcast with Odetta, Andre Watts, and Vince Giordano and the Nighthawks
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: we'll travel back to April 2005 and a show at The Town Hall in New York City. Odetta sings "Weeping Willow Blues" and "Rich Man," Andre Watts performs "Oiseaux Tristes" and Chopin's Nocturne in C-sharp minor, and Vince Giordano and the Nighthawks play "Happy Feet" and "You Shake That Thing." Plus: Pat Donohue leads The Guy's All-Star Shoe Band on a medley of Rolling Stones tunes, Guy Noir meets a parade of New York characters, and a message from Fritz Electronics. In Lake Wobegon, Irene Bunsen buys a load of manure to prepare her tomato plot.

item.title: February 10, 2001 rebroadcast with Greg Brown, Jeff Lang, and Jay Ungar and Molly Mason
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: a look back to February 2001 and a show at our home base, the Fitzgerald Theater in Saint Paul, Minnesota. Greg Brown performs "Cold Mean Winter" and "Like a Dog," Jeff Lang plays "Trainwreck 29" and "Bateman's Bay," and Jay Ungar and Molly Mason sing "Louisiana Wedding Bells" and "Prairie Spring." Plus: Dusty and Lefty pitch the Svendson Series 900 Air-ride Saddle, The Guy's All-Star Shoe Band plays the "St. Louis Blues," and a word from the American Duct Tape Council. In Lake Wobegon, Roger Hedlund visits the Chatterbox Cafe early on a cold morning and considers switching his farm from soybeans and corn to bluestem grass.

item.title: October 28, 2006 rebroadcast with Bonnie Raitt and The Wailin' Jennys
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: a show originally from October 2006 at the Fitzgerald Theater in Saint Paul, Minnesota. Bonnie Raitt performs "Women Be Wise" and "Angel from Montogmery" and The Wailin' Jennys sing "Glory Bound" and "Bright Morning Stars." Plus: The Guy's All-Star Shoe Band plays "Somethin's in the Attic," Guy Noir lends a hand to aspiring Broadway singer Lucille Potts, and a message from the Catchup Advisory Board. In Lake Wobegon, Sister Arvonne surreptitiously organizes Halloween activities.

item.title: June 30, 2007 rebroadcast with James Taylor, Jaime Laredo, Sharon Robinson, and Inga Swearingen
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: we'll play our 2006-2007 season finale from June 2007 at the Koussevitzky Music Shed at Tanglewood in Lenox, Massachusetts. James Taylor sings "Fourth of July" and "Sweet Baby James," violinist Jaime Laredo and cellist Sharon Robinson play a few pieces composed by Mr. Andy Stein, and Inga Swearingen joins Garrison on "All I Have to Do is Dream" and "I Think of You." Plus: Erica Rhodes joins the Royal Academy of Radio Actors, Guy Noir hunts down a stolen Stradivarius, and a message from Beebopareebop Rhubarb Pie and Rhubarb Pie Filling. In Lake Wobegon, Judy Ingqvist searches for elegance.

item.title: June 5, 2004 rebroadcast with Old Crow Medicine Show, Leon Redbone, Vince Giordano, Duke Heitger, and Butch Thompson
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: a June 2004 show from the Meadowbrook Farm Musical Arts Center in Guilford, New Hampshire. Old Crow Medicine Show play "Wagon Wheel" and "Tear it Down," Leon Redbone sings "Shiek of Araby" and "Ain't Misbehavin'," Vince Giordano joins us for "T'aint No Sin," and Duke Heitger and Butch Thompson sit in with The Guy's All-Star Shoe Band. Plus: Pat Donohue leads the band on "Another Friend Like Me," Guy Noir heads to New Hampshire for a little grandeur, and a message from the Cafe Boeuf Hampshire Nouveau. In Lake Wobegon, Mrs. Smiley's dog develops an unnatural attraction to a porcupine after eating Guilford tomatoes.

item.title: June 15, 1996 rebroadcast with Johnny Gimble and Flaco Jimenez
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: a trip all the way back to June 1996 and our show at the Laurie Auditorium in San Antonio, Texas. Johnny Gimble and Texas Swing perform "Somewhere South of San Antone" and the "Gardenia Waltz" and join Garrison on "Spanish Johnny," and Flaco Jiménez y su Conjunto play "El Gallo Copeton" and "Borracho #1." Plus: Dusty and Lefty stop in Texas to clean up after a long trail ride and meet up with Evelyn Beebalo, and a message from the Café Boeuf San Antonio. In Lake Wobegon, Pastor Inqvist meets a woman who tells him about a mystical experience at a Lutheran church in Minneapolis.

item.title: July 7, 2001 rebroadcast with Ralph Stanley, the City of Washington Pipe Band, and Maria Jette
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: a show originally from July 2001 at the Filene Center at Wolf Trap National Park for the Performing Arts in Vienna, Virginia. Ralph Stanley and the Clinch Mountain Boys perform "Man of Constant Sorrow" and "Rank Stranger," The City of Washington Pipe Band plays "Scotland the Brave," and Maria Jette sings "Nessun Dorma" and "Pie Jesu." Plus: The Guy's All-Star Shoe Band plays "Strike Up the Band" and a message from Bertha's Kitty Boutique. In Lake Wobegon, the Anderson boy returns after many years as a carnival entertainer.

item.title: July 4, 1998 rebroadcast with Iris DeMent, Kelley Hunt, and Calvin Trillin
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: we turn back to July 1998 for an Independence Day gem from the Starlight Theater in Kansas City, Missouri. Iris DeMent sings "These Hills" and "Sweet is the Melody," Kelley Hunt performs "Talk to Me" and "Back in the Saddle," and Calvin Trillin reads from his book Family Man. Plus: a look back into history and the signing of the Declaration of Independence, Pat Donohue and Andy Stein play "Wild Man," and messages from the Cafe Boeuf Kansas City and the Professional Organization of English Majors. In Lake Wobegon, Irene Bunsen gloats when her tomato plants outstrip her brother-in-law Clarence's crop.

item.title: June 28, 2014 rebroadcast with Keb' Mo', The Wailin' Jennys, Rob Fisher, and The DiGiallonardo Sisters
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: a June 2014 rewind from the Koussevitzky Music Shed at Tanglewood in Lenox, Massachusetts. Keb' Mo' plays "The Old Me Better" and "More for Your Money," The Wailin' Jennys perform "Swing Low, Sail High" and "Asleep at Last," and Rob Fisher joins us for "Junk Man's Rag" and teams up with The DiGiallonardo Sisters for "Songs My Mother Taught Me" and "Ain't No Sweet Man Worth the Salt of My Tears." Plus: Guy Noir heads to the Berkshires and meets a troupe of singing animals, The Guy's All-Star Shoe Band plays Mendelssohn's nocturne from A Midsummer Night's Dream, and a message from our sponsor Murphy's Plumbing. In Lake Wobegon, a deerfly bite helps the Whippets continue their winning season.

item.title: June 20, 2015 rebroadcast with Elvin Bishop, Rachel Barton Pine, and John Fullbright
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: we return to June 2015 and our show at the Ravinia Festival in Highland Park, Illinois. Elvin Bishop plays "Old School" and "Everybody's in the Same Boat," Rachel Barton Pine performs Amy Beach's Romance for Violin & Piano, Op. 23 and "Wiegenlied," and John Fullbright sings "Blameless" and "I Only Pray at Night." Plus: Guy Noir meets up with Studs Terkel, a few scripts for Father's Day, and Howard Levy sits in with the band to play his tune "Twenty Eight." In Lake Wobegon, Clarence Bunsen sleeps on his boat so he can do some thinking in the middle of the night.

item.title: June 6, 2015 rebroadcast with Jeremy Denk, Heather Masse, and The DiGiallonardo Sisters
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: a June 2015 rewind from the CMAC Marvin Sands Performing Arts Center in Canandaigua, NY. Jeremy Denk performs selections from Mendelssohn and Haydn, Heather Masse sings "Songbird" and "Vivid," and The DiGiallonardo Sisters turn in "Sentimental Gentleman from Georgia" and "Nowhere Man." Plus: Guy Noir takes a job at a camp in upstate New York, and a message from our sponsor, the Vineyards of Canandaigua. In Lake Wobegon, the class of 2015 pulls off one of the better graduation pranks in recent memory.

item.title: June 7, 2014 rebroadcast with Ann and Nancy Wilson, Greg Brown, Jearlyn Steele, and Hilary Thavis
May 29, 2010 rebroadcast with Tom Rush, Gillian Welch, and Inga Swearingen
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: a Memorial Day weekend show from 2010 at the Filene Center at Wolf Trap National Park for the Performing Arts in Vienna, Virginia. Tom Rush performs "Merrimack County" and "Child's Song," Gillian Welch joins us for "Someone Like You" and "Sweet Tooth," and Inga Swearingen sings "Lazy Afternoon." Plus: a few patriotic sing-alongs, a twin fiddle medley from The Guy's All-Star Shoe Band featuring Andy Stein and Gabe Witcher, and Guy Noir digs up some dirt on multimillionaire candidate Boodle Bendix. In Lake Wobegon, Irene Bunsen calls into a radio station at 3:30 in the morning.

item.title: May 31, 2014 rebroadcast with Colin Hay, Los Texmaniacs, and Lynn Peterson
May 8, 2010 rebroadcast with Dick Hyman, Vince Giordano, and Andra Suchy
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: a Mother's Day show originally from May 2010 at The Town Hall in New York City. Pianist and composer Dick Hyman plays "Thinking About Bix" and "Ostrich Walk," Vince Giordano sits in with The Guy's All-Star Shoe Band for "Take Your Tomorrows," and Andra Suchy joins Garrison on "The Sweetest Gift, a Mother's Smile" and "Mama Say a Prayer." Plus: Mr. Pat Donohue leads the Shoe Band -- with a little help from Vince, trumpeter Randy Sandke, and Andy Stein on violin and saxophone -- on the "Lonesome Midtown Blues," Erica Rhodes joins our Royal Academy of Radio Actors for a few Mother's Day scripts, and Guy Noir tracks down a missing St. Olaf student in NYC. In Lake Wobegon, Carl Krebsbach becomes a spectacle after being covered in plum blossoms during a storm.

item.title: May 10, 2014 rebroadcast with Brad Paisley, Sturgill Simpson, Sam Bush, Stuart Duncan, and Brian Dan Christensen
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: we look back to May 2014 and a show at the Ryman Auditorium in Nashville, Tennessee. Brad Paisley sings "Southern Comfort Zone" and -- with a lyrical assist from the host -- "Geology"; Sturgill Simpson plays "Turtles All the Way Down" and "Long White Line"; Sam Bush and Stuart Duncan team up for "My Little Girl in Tennessee"; and Brian Dan Christensen favors us with a few classics from The King, Elvis Presley, including "Heartbreak Hotel" in Danish. Plus: Guy Noir visits the world-famous Bluebird Cafe, Garrison sings the "Methodist Blues" with Rich Dworsky and our band, and a message from Biloxi Brand Bass Boats. In Lake Wobegon: Pastor Haugen irritates his secretary Marlene.

item.title: April 25, 2015 rebroadcast with Brooklyn Rider, The Wailin' Jennys, and Sharon Olds
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: we'll revisit an April 2015 show from The Town Hall in New York City, New York. Brooklyn Rider perform "Show Me" and "Little Birdie," The Wailin' Jennys sing "Deeper Well" and Gillian Welch's "Orphan Girl," and poet Sharon Olds reads "Material Ode" and "Where She Is Now." Plus: Rich Dworsky and the Dworsky New York Orchestra play "I Can See Summer," a script for National Poetry Month and a word from Fred Farrell Animal Calls. In Lake Wobegon, Arlene Bunsen counsels her goddaughter Charlotte against taking up the trombone.

item.title: April 20, 2002 rebroadcast with Kate Rusby, Billy Collins, and Fiddlers 4
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: a 15-year rewind to April 2002 and a show at The Town Hall in New York City. Kate Rusby sings "Botany Bay" and "I Courted a Sailor," Billy Collins reads "Love" and "Forgetfulness," and the Fiddlers 4 play "I Know" and "I Wish I Knew How It Would Feel To Be Free." Plus: The Guy's All-Star Shoe Band plays Rich Dworsky's "Southern Hospitality"; a New York, New York travelogue; and a message from the Catchup Advisory Board. In Lake Wobegon, high school students prepare for life after graduation.

item.title: May 2, 2015 rebroadcast with the Goshen College Chamber Choir, Lily and Madeleine, and Ethan Setiawan
April 5, 2008 rebroadcast with Brad Paisley, Jean Redpath, Ron Padgett, and Kimberly Williams-Paisley
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: an April 2008 rewind from The Town Hall in New York City. Brad Paisley plays "I'm Still a Guy" and "Letter to Me"; our friend Jean Redpath sings "If You Could Wait a Moment Longer" and "The Old Woman"; Ron Padgett reads his poems "The Drink" and "Bastille Day"; and actress Kimberly Williams-Paisley joins us for a few scripts, including as a demolition expert in an episode of Guy Noir. Plus: Rich Dworsky and The Guy's All-Star Shoe Band get a little six-string help from Mr. Paisley on "Cruisin' Downtown," Garrison sings "It's Only a Cyber Moon," and messages from our sponsors Beebopareebop Rhubarb Pie and Neurodyne Industries. In Lake Wobegon, Darlene meets a man on Match.com. Download this week's News from Lake Wobegon

item.title: April 2, 2016 rebroadcast with Vasen, Heather Masse, and Rob Fisher
March 29, 1997 rebroadcast with Greg Brown, Diana Krall, Kate MacKenzie, and Robin and Linda Williams
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: we spin the clock back 20 whole years to March 1997 and a show at Saint Paul, Minnesota's Fitzgerald Theater. Mr. Greg Brown joins us for "Vivid" and "Why Don't You Just Go Home?"; Diana Krall and her trio perform "I'm an Errand Girl for Rhythm" and "Ghost of a Chance (I Don't Stand A)"; and our friends Kate MacKenzie and Robin and Linda Williams team up with Garrison as The Hopeful Gospel Quartet to sing "Your Long Journey" and Gillian Welch's "By the Mark." Plus: Dusty and Lefty tangle with a herd of free-range chickens, a message from the Cafe Boeuf St. Paul and Bertha's Kitty Boutique, and Marvin and Mavis Smiley showcase a few songs off their album of classic spring tunes. In Lake Wobegon, the last of the rhubarb gets made into pies at the Chatterbox Cafe. Download this week's News from Lake Wobegon

item.title: March 29, 2014 classic rebroadcast with Willie Watson, Jearlyn and Jevetta Steele, Butch Thompson, and Hilary Thavis
item.description:
This week's classic rebroadcast: we revisit a March 2014 show from the Fitzgerald Theater in Saint Paul, Minnesota. Willie Watson performs "Mexican Cowboy" and "Keep it Clean"; Jearlyn and Jevetta Steele turn in "Season of Jubilee" and "Hit the Road, Jack"; and Butch Thompson plays "River Sing to Me" and accompanies Hilary Thavis on "Mamie's Blues." Plus: Guy Noir struggles with a cash shortage, Garrison sings "Argonne," and a brief word from our sponsor Lutheran Air. In Lake Wobegon, the Lutheran Church holds its Lenten soup suppers.
Download this week's News from Lake Wobegon

item.title: March 2, 2013 classic rebroadcast with Emmylou Harris and Rodney Crowell, Heather Masse and Jed Wilson, and Jearlyn and Jevetta Steele
March 1, 2008 rebroadcast with The Wailin' Jennys, The Boys of the Lough, and Robert Bly
item.description: This week: we'll return to March 2008 and a broadcast from the Fitzgerald Theater on Exchange Street in Saint Paul, Minnesota. Our friends The Wailin' Jennys sing "Beautiful Dawn" and "Driving"; The Boys of the Lough join us from Ireland and Scotland for "The Keane Reels" and "Beauty Deas An Oileain"; and Minnesota's first Poet Laureate, Robert Bly, reads a few selections from his catalog. Plus: Pat Donohue and The Guy's All-Star Shoe Band play "Hawaiian Blues" and "Breakin' the Ice," Guy Noir seeks out a cure for cabin fever, and a message from the Partnership of English Majors. In Lake Wobegon, Alan Jansky returns for a visit after living in Santa Barbara for years. Download this week's News from Lake Wobegon

item.title: February 15, 2003 rebroadcast with Old Crow Medicine Show, Suzy Bogguss, Tommy Emmanuel, and Sam Bush
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: we look back to February 2003 and our show at the Grand Ole Opry House in Nashville, Tennessee. Old Crow Medicine Show perform "Falling on My Knees" and "Trials and Troubles," Suzy Bogguss sings "Letting Go" and "Cupid," Tommy Emmanuel plays "Train to Dusseldorf" and "The Tall Fiddler," and Sam Bush sits in with The Guy's All-Star Shoe Band for "Bushwhacked" and more. Plus: Dusty and Lefty visit the Country Music Hall of Fame, and messages from our sponsors Sam Bush Belts, the American Duct Tape Council, and the Catchup Advisory Board. In Lake Wobegon, rumors swirl after Pastor Inqvist spends a few days in Nashville. Download the News from Lake Wobegon

item.title: February 28, 2015 rebroadcast with Brandi Carlile and Jearlyn Steele
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: a return to February 2015 and a show from the State Theatre in Minneapolis, Minnesota. Brandi Carlile sings "Wherever is Your Heart" and "The Eye," and Jearlyn Steele brings the house down with "Dancing in the Street." Plus: Guy Noir talks with his therapist, Penelope; Rich Dworsky and The Dayton's Parking Ramp Band play "Hennepin Happenin'" in honor of downtown Minneapolis's main drag; and a message from coffee -- it stimulates your system. In Lake Wobegon, Cindy Hedlund meets someone online after just a few months as a widow.

item.title: February 14, 2004 rebroadcast with Doc Watson and Sam Bush
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: a look back to our February 2004 in Spartanburg, South Carolina. Flatpicking icon Doc Watson joins us for "Milk Cow Blues," "East Bound Freight Train," and more; and bluegrass madman Sam Bush plays "Crossroads" and "Ralph's Banjo Special." Plus: a few scripts from various early-2000s shows, with our Royal Academy of Radio Actors, Tim Russell, Sue Scott, and Fred Newman; and Pat Donohue leads The Guy's All-Star Shoe Band on "Boogie Woogie Baby."

item.title: February 1, 1997 rebroadcast with BeauSoleil and Gil and Orli Shaham
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: we're rewinding 20 whole years to February 1997 and a show from the Fitzgerald Theater in Saint Paul, Minnesota. BeauSoleil play "L'Amour Ou La Folie" and the "Eunice Two-Step," and Gil and Orli Shaham with a few Dvorak pieces for violin and piano, including the Allegro Maestoso from 4 Romantic Pieces. Plus: Guy Noir gets a little stock market advice (hint: invest in flower futures); more comedy and drama from our Royal Academy of Radio Actors, Tim Russell, Sue Scott, and Tom Keith; and Andy Stein and The Guy's All-Star Shoe Band play "Shine." In Lake Wobegon, Leland buys the Everett house using money he's made running insurance scams.

item.title: January 24, 2015 rebroadcast with Nellie McKay, Robin and Linda Williams, and Kirsten Dierking
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: a January 2015 show from the Fitzgerald Theater in Saint Paul, Minnesota. Nellie McKay sings "Not So Sweet Martha Lorraine" and "Itchycoo Park," our friends Robin and Linda Williams perform "Dixie Highway Sign" and "Raised By the Railroad Line," and poet Kirsten Dierking reads "Wilderness" and "Nut Hatch." Plus: Guy Noir works security at the Saint Paul Winter Carnival, a message from the Master App by Fritz Electronics, and Rich Dworsky and The Exchange Street Quartet back up the host on an updated version of Offenbach's Barcarolle. In Lake Wobegon, Senator K. Thorvaldson finally heads south for the winter.

item.title: January 25, 2014 rebroadcast with Rhonda Vincent and the Rage, Mike Compton and Joe Newberry, and The Nightingale Trio
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: a show originally from January 2014 at our home base in Saint Paul, Minnesota, the Fitzgerald Theater. Rhonda Vincent and the Rage play "Busy City" and "It's Never Too Late," Mike Compton and Joe Newberry perform "Lazy John" and the "How Long Blues," and The Nightingale Trio sing "Tsangala" and "Ko Shto Mi e Milo." Plus: Garrison enlists Mr. Newberry for a little help with "The Frozen Logger," a message from Fred Farrell and our Royal Academy of Radio Actors, and Rich Dworsky and The Guy's All-Star Shoe Band deliver "Nao Me Toques." In Lake Wobegon, Pastor Liz's boyfriend Cliff attends a service at the Lutheran Church.

item.title: January 21, 2012 rebroadcast with Joshua Bell and Jearlyn and Jevetta Steele
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: we return to January 2012 and a broadcast from the Fitzgerald Theater. Violin virtuoso Joshua Bell plays Chopin's Nocturne in C-sharp minor and Sarasate's Zigeunerweisen"; and the singing sisters of soul, Jearlyn and Jevetta Steele, join us for "Jump, Jive, an' Wail" and "This Day." Plus: Dusty and Lefty head to Minnesota's Kandihohi County, a visit to the Cafe Boeuf, and Pat Donohue and The Guy's All-Star Shoe Band play "Salty Dog." In Lake Wobegon, a spell of warm weather puts those who suffer from "Pump Handle Phobia" at ease.

item.title: October 26, 2013 rebroadcast with The Milk Carton Kids, Hilary Thavis, and Tony Thomas
December 31, 2016 rebroadcast with Old Crow Medicine Show, Emmylou Harris and Jon Randall, Rhonda Vincent and the Rage, Doyle Lawson and Quicksilver, Suzy Bogguss, and more
item.description: This week's classic rebroadcast: a 10-year rewind to our New Year's Eve show from the Ryman Auditorium in Nashville, Tennessee on December 31, 2006. Old Crow Medicine Show ask "Are You from Dixie?"; Rhonda Vincent and the Rage play "All American Bluegrass Girl"; Doyle Lawson and Quicksilver turn things up past 11, acoustically, with "Sadie's Got a New Dress"; Suzy Bogguss sings "What Are You Doing New Year's Eve?"; Emmylou Harris and Jon Randall perform the classic "If I Could Only Win Your Love"; Cowboy Jack Clement joins the band for his own classic, "Guess Things Happen That Way"; and our friends Robin and Linda Williams drop by for a tune or two, including a slow-burning "Ramblin' Man." Plus: a message from the Catchup Advisory Board and a visit to the Cafe Boeuf courtesy of Tim Russell and Fred Newman; an extra-wide Shoe Band, with Nashville pickers Buddy Emmons, Stuart Duncan, Sam Bush, and Jerry Douglas joining Richard Dworsky and the Guy's; and Garrison shares a few notes on how Lake Wobegon is preparing for the New Year. Download this week's News from Lake Wobegon Notes from Richard Dworsky on this week's rebroadcast: If you are a country music fan, this show is definitely for you -- amazing artists doing their signature tunes. Pardon me for using the Lord's name in vain but OMG! Emmylou Harris singing "If I Could Only Win Your Love," great bluegrass from Rhonda Vincent and the Rage, AND Doyle Lawson and Quicksilver! Old Crow Medicine Show doing their killer tune "Wagon Wheel," country songstress Suzy Bogguss doing an elegant version of the 1940s Frank Loesser standard "What Are You Doing New Year's Eve?" Our old friends Robin and Linda Williams doing their "Rollin' and Ramblin'." And our Guy's All-Star Shoe Band was augmented by a bunch of the greatest pickers who ever walked the Earth: Sam Bush on mandolin, Jerry Douglas on Dobro, Stuart Duncan on fiddle, and Buddy Emmons on pedal steel guitar. As bandleader, I have to point to soloists on the fly and, due to them sitting in a line behind me, it was hard to tell which player I was pointing to. But I joked afterwards that it didn't matter, 'cause whoever ran with that solo played a fantastic break. And last, but not least, we had the late, great Cowboy Jack Clement singing a couple of his tunes. It was always a pleasure and honor to accompany him. Jack wrote hit songs for Johnny Cash, recorded and produced Jerry Lee Lewis's very first demo (and first few records) at Sun Studio in Memphis, and produced everybody from Roy Orbison to the band U2! He was a funny guy and a true legend, and is greatly missed. The Ryman Auditorium was where Garrison first got his inspiration to create A Prairie Home Companion, and it's always fun to watch him perform in that historic hall. To wind up the night, Garrison led "Will the Circle Be Unbroken" as our full ensemble closing number -- soul stirring! I can't believe 10 years have passed since this great New Year's Eve show. Happy New Year to you all.

item.title: December 24, 2016 rebroadcast with Itzhak Perlman and the Klezmer Conservatory Band, Gillian Welch, Joel Grey, Rob Fisher, and The DiGiallonardo Sisters
item.description:
This week: a December 2011 rebroadcast from The Town Hall on West 43rd Street in New York City. Itzhak Perlman plays "Tambourin Chinois" with pianist John Root and "Heyser Bulgar" with the Klezmer Conservatory Band, Gillian Welch sings "Dixie Line" and "Six White Horses," Joel Grey and Rob Fisher team up for "Be Like a Bluebird," and The DiGiallonardo Sisters perform "Santa Lucia" with the host. Plus: Garrison tells about the annual Sons of Knute Christmas Dance and Dinner; Richard Dworsky leads The Guy's All-Star Shoe band on "S'Vivon" and "God Rest Ye Merry Gentlemen" and plays his own "Short Attention Span Christmas Medley"; our Royal Academy of Radio Actors, Tim Russell, Sue Scott, and Fred Newman, with a look at the joys of the Christmas season and a message from the Catchup Advisory Board; and a holiday sing-along to close out the show. In Lake Wobegon, Christmas is a time of small disasters, but it is through hard times that we get closer together: the Tolleruds reluctantly accept a gift from a NYC relative, Lake Wobegon Lutheran Church celebrates St. Lucia Day, and more. Download this week's News from Lake Wobegon
Notes from Rob Fisher on this week's rebroadcast: That particular appearance on APHC with Joel Grey weaves many threads together. Joel and I arrived between two performances of the Broadway revival of Anything Goes playing directly across the street from The Town Hall at the Sondheim Theater: Joel as Moonface Martin, public enemy #1, and yours truly conducting. We dashed across the street between shows and performed with no sound check, which is only possible when everyone already knows everything about what's going on. Joel and I both knew Garrison and how the show works. Years before (25 years?) Garrison had asked me to bring Joel onto the broadcast to perform his father's material -- that's Mickey Katz, definitely worth a Google. It was amazing to be in the lineup with the DiGiallonardo Sisters, but weird not to be performing with them, especially since we had recorded a holiday album together. As I write this, I'm on Oahu, soon to rehearse "Mele Kalikimaka" with the Hawaii Symphony. Out here everyone knows the words and sings along.
